<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 907, 92]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the extension of a spring supporting a wooden strip, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 98, 801, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 850, 405]]<|/det|>
One end of the strip is at point P. The strip has length \(L\) and is at an angle \(\theta\) to the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 922, 452]]<|/det|>
The spring is attached to the strip by a wire at a distance \(d\) from point P. The wire is at an angle \(\beta\) to the strip. The spring has extension \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 464, 567, 483]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(x\) and \(\theta\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 490, 586, 518]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{W L}{2}\cos \theta = k x d\sin \beta\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 524, 645, 544]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is the spring constant of the spring and \(W\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 710, 574]]<|/det|>
Design a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(x\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 571, 670, 590]]<|/det|>
Explain how your results could be used to determine a value for \(W.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 602, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
You should draw a diagram, on page 3, showing the arrangement of your equipment. In your account you should pay particular attention to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 650, 395, 668]]<|/det|>
● the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 676, 410, 694]]<|/det|>
● the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 346, 720]]<|/det|>
● the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 728, 351, 746]]<|/det|>
● the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 753, 447, 771]]<|/det|>
● any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A Geiger–Müller (G–M) tube is a device that can detect beta-radiation. A student places paper between a radioactive source emitting beta-radiation and a G–M tube, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 112, 870, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 260, 532, 279]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 737, 310]]<|/det|>
The G–M tube is connected to a rate-meter which records the count rate \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 806, 341]]<|/det|>
The thickness \(t\) of the paper is measured in two different places using a micrometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 354, 692, 373]]<|/det|>
The student repeats the experiment for different thicknesses of paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 569, 403]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(R\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 414, 546, 433]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_0\mathrm{e}^{-\mu t}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 446, 653, 465]]<|/det|>
where \(R_0\) is the count rate without any paper and \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 478, 144, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 477, 660, 497]]<|/det|>
A graph is plotted of \(\ln R\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 508, 611, 527]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 662, 917, 682]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 694, 920, 713]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 710, 920, 728]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|> The two measurements of thickness are \(t_{\mathrm{1}}\) and \(t_{\mathrm{2}}\). Values of \(t_{\mathrm{1}}\), \(t_{\mathrm{2}}\) and \(R\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 103, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 133, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
\(t_{1}/\text{mm}\)\(t_{2}/\text{mm}\)average \(t/\text{mm}\)\(R/\text{s}^{-1}\)\(\ln (R/\text{s}^{-1})\)
0.190.1347.7
0.220.2844.0
0.390.4538.2
0.580.5434.3
0.640.6831.7
0.780.7429.7
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 756, 479]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of average \(t/\text{mm}\) and \(\ln (R/\text{s}^{-1})\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 477, 541, 494]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in average \(t\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 477, 920, 495]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 508, 144, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 508, 180, 526]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 508, 594, 526]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(\ln (R/\mathrm{s}^{-1})\) against average \(t / \mathrm{mm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 457, 541]]<|/det|> Include error bars for average \(t\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 523, 920, 541]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 555, 181, 573]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 555, 920, 587]]<|/det|> Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Both lines should be clearly labelled. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 570, 920, 588]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 600, 180, 618]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 600, 920, 632]]<|/det|> Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
gradient = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 260, 920, 279]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 148, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 291, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
Using your answers to (a), (c)(iii) and (c)(iv), determine the values of \(\mu\) and \(R_0\). Include the absolute uncertainties in your values and include appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 508, 917, 526]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\mu =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 539, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
<form>\(R_0 =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 555, 920, 572]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 584, 146, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 584, 682, 602]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated using a different thickness of paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 616, 685, 633]]<|/det|>
Determine the value of \(t\) that would give a value of \(R\) of \(20.0 \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 766, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>t = .................................................... mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 797, 920, 814]]<|/det|>
